moment in history of taste'
An exhibition, arranged to illustrate a moment in the history of
taste, is now in progress in the main
lobby of Gilman hall. There is a collection of French drawings and paintings illustrating the progression in

accommodate all those desirous of
knowledge of any phase of the work
connected with the exhibition.

Both sides of the current controversy over the participation of the
United States in World War II were
presented by two members of the
Hopkins history department Thursday morning, when the Liberal club
sponsored an American Day freshman assembly.
The speakers were Dr W Stull
Holt, Associate Professor of History,
and Dr Eric F Goldman, Instructor
in History. The assembly, which was
presented by the Liberal club, had as
its topic "Europe's Fate—America's
Hope."
Favoring the entrance of this
nation into the conflict on the side of
the Allies, Dr Holt declared, "I think
it's our fight! I think the choice is one
between international anarchy and a
world organized to enforce peace. Just
so long as the world is going on the
jungle basis, just so long as war is
only the concern of two nations,
just so long there will be war."
He predicted that if the present
military regime in Germany wins the
conflict that the United States will
see the greatest military preparations
in its history. At present, he added,
this nation is "depending upon the
happy accident of the British fleet,
preserving a legal neutrality, yet
exploiting our economic resources."
"It's not enough to insure the
victory of the Allies or to place our
resources at their command, but we
must also organize on the basis that
a breach of the peace. is of concern
to all." He added that Germany must
not be defeated solely by France and
England, if a fair peace is to be
"I think that European civilization,
now endangered by the most brutal
force the world has seen since
Napoleon, is worth fighting for to
preserve," he concluded.
Sharp issue was taken with this
position by Dr Goldman, who declared
he could see no possibilty of a German
victory in the face of the tremendous
economic forces concentrated against
her, and that therefore there existed
no danger to America.
"I don't believe this is a war of
ideologies," he pointed out. "It is
merely one of a series of age-old
struggles of European nations striving to preserve their hegemonies."
He declared himself even more
firmly convinced that our entrance
into the war would not bring about
fair peace, but that the resulting
settlement would make the Treaty a
Versailles "look like a document of
saints". The only way to achieve the
collective security which would impose peace would be thru participation of the United States, and this
would be done in the face of unanimous opposition within this nation.

Frosh commission
hears 'date' talk
The Freshman commission, last
Tuesday evening, heard Bill Hammaker, director of the Y M C A,
lead a discussion on: "What I am
looking for in a date." His talk was in
discussion form, the members of the
commission giving their personal
opinions on the subject.
Although there were a variety of
opinions, it was generally agreed
that the ultimate objective of dating
is marriage. It was also stated that
the superficial motive was to have
a good time.
Hammaker stated that "one who
dates a girl steady, without serious
intentions is doing harm to the girl
as well as to himself." He also suggested that the freshmen should
learn "to know girls as persons„ and
not just as girls".
Hammaker proposed a method of
developing comradeship with members of the opposite sex in order to
assist in a happy marriage. "The success or failure of married life depends a great deal on the pre-martial relationships during dates.
Mr. Hammaker read passages from
books on the subject of dating. These
books are available in the Y office
to all who wish to borrow them.
